headline.main: PLIMPTON AND STYRON READ WORKS AT PEN SERIES

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: POETS, PLAYWRIGHTS, EDITORS, ESSAYISTS AND NOVELISTS

results.snippet: The sounds of Tchaikovsky reverberated throughout the Royale theater on Broadway last night, played by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. However, the Philharmonic was not in attendance - just one of its part-time members, George Plimpton, the...
results.lead_paragraph: The sounds of Tchaikovsky reverberated throughout the Royale theater on Broadway last night, played by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. However, the Philharmonic was not in attendance - just one of its part-time members, George Plimpton, the author, editor and dilettante par excellence. Winding up his hourlong portion of this PEN Celebration, the seventh of eight Sunday nights on Broadway with noted writers, Mr. Plimpton elected to play a phonograph recording of brief portions of the last movement of Tchaikovsky's Second Symphony, where, as the percussionist on the recording, his role was to hit the gong. Mr. Plimpton acquitted himself handsomely on the recording, but on stage, holding in rapt anticipation the gong he had brought for his big moment, he struck several counts too early. But by that time he had already made a big hit with the near-capacity audience that turned out on a dreary night.

results.snippet: Crew members of the space shuttle Atlantis, their seven-day orbital mission nearly behind them, said today that their flight had taken a significant step toward the establishment of a large space station.   Answering questions radioed to the craft...

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Crew members of the space shuttle Atlantis, their seven-day orbital mission nearly behind them, said today that their flight had taken a significant step toward the establishment of a large space station. Answering questions radioed to the craft from reporters at the Johnson Space Flight Center in Houston, the astronauts reported progress not only in working out space station construction techniques, but in developing a gravity-free pharmaceutical factory to be based at the station. The six men and one woman aboard Atlantis spent their final full day in space concluding an array of experiments and preparing for their scheduled landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., at 4:33 P.M. Eastern standard time Tuesday.

results.snippet: Shirley Kagan and Brenda Bernstein of the ''In The Spirit'' gallery in New York City are disputing Representative Stephen J. Solarz's assertion that he has arranged for the first transportation of a mezuza into space. Mr. Solarz, a Brooklyn...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Shirley Kagan and Brenda Bernstein of the ''In The Spirit'' gallery in New York City are disputing Representative Stephen J. Solarz's assertion that he has arranged for the first transportation of a mezuza into space. Mr. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat, said that, at his request, Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat, agreed to take a mezuza with him on the space shuttle Dec. 18. A mezuza is a small piece of parchment inscribed with passages from Deuteronomy and rolled up in a case that is affixed to the doorways of observant Jews. Mr. Solarz said that his would be ''the first mezuza in space'' and that he would probably keep it at his office when it comes back.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE BACK AFTER NEARLY FLAWLESS MISSION

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here today, concluding a nearly flawless weeklong mission that included the first construction project in space and three successful satellite launchings.   After puncturing the air over Los Angeles with a...

byline.original: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here today, concluding a nearly flawless weeklong mission that included the first construction project in space and three successful satellite launchings. After puncturing the air over Los Angeles with a trail of double sonic booms, the Atlantis glided up to the Mojave Desert, made a 170-degree left turn and landed on the large concrete runway here. It rolled to a stop at 1:33 P.M., Pacific standard time. ''Welcome home, Atlantis - great landing,'' Mission Control told the seven crew members, led by the mission commander, Lieut. Col. Brewster H. Shaw Jr. Shuttles usually land on endless dirt runways at the base. But a week of rain left scattered puddles on the usually dry lake bed runways. Remnants of rain clouds and wispy mare'stails filled the sky as the Atlantis returned to the Earth, seven days and 2.8 million miles after its blazing nighttime liftoff from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia, the flagship of the fleet, is scheduled for its first flight in more than two years this week, carrying a seven-man crew that includes a Congressman from Florida and the first Hispanic American astronaut. The launching...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia, the flagship of the fleet, is scheduled for its first flight in more than two years this week, carrying a seven-man crew that includes a Congressman from Florida and the first Hispanic American astronaut. The launching of America's first reusable spacecraft, which has undergone an 18-month overhaul, is scheduled for 7 o'clock Wednesday morning.

headline.main: From the South Bronx To the Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: When the space shuttle Columbia lifts off tomorrow morning from Cape Canaveral, Fla., 30 students from the South Bronx will be watching.   ''I thought this would be specially good for the kids,'' Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx,...

byline.original: By Susan Heller Anderson and David W. Dunlap

results.lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Columbia lifts off tomorrow morning from Cape Canaveral, Fla., 30 students from the South Bronx will be watching. ''I thought this would be specially good for the kids,'' Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx, said.

headline.main: SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING SCHEDULED FOR TODAY POSTPONED 24 HOURS

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today postponed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia by 24 hours because tired ground crew workers had fallen behind in their countdown tasks.   ''Essentially, there were too many tasks to...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today postponed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia by 24 hours because tired ground crew workers had fallen behind in their countdown tasks. ''Essentially, there were too many tasks to complete and too little time to complete them,'' said George Diller, a NASA spokesman.

headline.main: CONGRESSMAN SET TO GO UP IN SPACE SHUTTLE TODAY

results.snippet: The countdown went smoothly today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on Thursday. Among the seven crew members is Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who heads the House subcommittee that oversees the budget of the National...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The countdown went smoothly today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on Thursday. Among the seven crew members is Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who heads the House subcommittee that oversees the budget of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Barring last-minute problems or bad weather, the Columbia is scheduled to begin the five-day mission at 7 A.M. The goals of the flight are to launch an RCA communications satellite and to carry out a series of experiments in materials science, astrophysics, technology development and life sciences. In addition, two experiments will try to solve some of the riddles of Halley's comet.
